wordpressPost.title: From the C-Suite: Three Takes on Positive Change
wordpressPost.content:
Imagine how people reacted to the idea of walking on the moon, when President Kennedy announced it, back in 1961.

Looking up at the sky, most people dismissed the idea in utter disbelief. Despite those doubts, the moon landing was accomplished eight years later. As Apollo 11 set down on the lunar landscape and Commander Neil Armstrong described one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind, a great cheer rose up from the NASA control room and roared around the world.
Who exactly was in that NASA control room?

Have a look:

The manager in charge of that room of rocket scientists later analyzed the average age of his team: twenty-six. So these employees were 18 years old when the mission was first announced. For them, the moonshot was well underway by the time they graduated from college.

Moonshot Lesson: it’s easier to accept transformation, and contribute to it, when the change is already in motion, clearly articulated and widely supported by committed leadership.
Fast forward to today:
Our generation of millennials have grown up around substantial change’ the global explosion of the smart phone, the legalization of gay marriage, practically ubiquitous Internet. Such influences inspire them to demand an accelerated pace for solutions to a host of issues: workplace equality, race and social justice, the environment, public health and security issues. Millennials are disrupting the deficiencies of entrenched systems, from taxis to travel to cable TV.
Where there’s demand there’s money. Which brings us to the top 3 takeaways from the Investor Summit we attended on Thursday, organized by Ceres at the United Nations headquarters, New York City. More than 500 investors and business leaders gathered for a conversation about everything today’s generations are demanding: transformative change, unleashing capital, responsible leadership, top-down/bottom-up solutions, and the most remarkable business opportunity in history.
Our top 3 take-aways:
1. Top Talent Demands Positive Change
‘. if you want to recruit the best and the brightest, they are all asking about the environment. So companies that aren’t doing anything to be environmentally friendly won’t get the talent. The public is a lot smarter than we give them credit for. They know there’s a problem, they want to do something about it. People are pushing this, pushing companies to change.
Michael Bloomberg, Founder of Bloomberg LP and Bloomberg Philanthropies & 3-term mayor of New York City; United Nations special envoy for Climate Change
2. Corporations Support Positive Change
Sustainability starts in our own company: it’s our teammates, our wellness activities, philanthropic work, volunteer work. This is what motivates our team– it’s who we are as a company.
Brian Moynihan, Bank of America, Chairman of the Board and CEO
3. Positive Change is Well Underway
Think of a big open field, where everyone used to be fighting. Now, this year, we suddenly have the foundation for a house. And, we are going to build that house. We’re building it for our children and our grandchildren.-
Michael Eckhart, Citigroup, Managing Director & Global Head of Environmental Finance and Sustainability
Today’s business leaders embrace unprecedented change as their responsibility, and they’re working hard to get everyone on board. At WeSpire, our team has the privilege of witnessing positive change being fostered at today’s leading global corporations.
How are you influencing positive change like this within your own organization?
